Any linear two-terminal circuit can be replaced by:

• A voltage source V_th in SERIES with
• A resistance R_th

     R_th
A ○──/\/\/──┐
           │
          V_th
           │
B ○────────┘

Any linear two-terminal circuit can be replaced by:

• A current source I_N in PARALLEL with
• A resistance R_N

A ○────┬────○
       │
      R_N  I_N↑
       │
B ○────┴────○

The OPEN-CIRCUIT voltage at the terminals.

Procedure:
1. Remove the load (leave terminals open)
2. Calculate voltage between terminals A and B
3. That voltage = V_th

The SHORT-CIRCUIT current between terminals.

Procedure:
1. Short-circuit the terminals (connect A to B)
2. Calculate current through the short
3. That current = I_N

Method 1 (no dependent sources):
• Turn off all independent sources
• V-source → short, I-source → open
• Calculate resistance between terminals

Method 2 (any circuit):
R_th = V_th / I_sc

Thévenin → Norton:
• I_N = V_th / R_th
• R_N = R_th

Norton → Thévenin:
• V_th = I_N × R_N
• R_th = R_N

The resistance is ALWAYS the same!

When finding R_th:

• Voltage source → SHORT CIRCUIT
  (V=0 is just a wire)

• Current source → OPEN CIRCUIT
  (I=0 is just a break)

• Dependent source → KEEP ACTIVE!
  (Never turn off)

With load R_L connected to Thévenin equivalent:

I_L = V_th / (R_th + R_L)

V_L = V_th × R_L / (R_th + R_L)

This is just a voltage divider!

1. Simplify complex circuits to 2 elements

2. Analyze multiple loads easily
   (One equivalent, many loads)

3. Find maximum power transfer
   (R_load = R_th)

4. Understand source behavior
   (V_th = ideal voltage, R_th = internal resistance)

The terminal V-I relationship is linear:

V = V_th - I × R_th

• V-intercept (I=0): V_th (open circuit)
• I-intercept (V=0): I_N = V_th/R_th (short circuit)
• Slope: -R_th
